review.title: Verifier Theory and Unverifiability
review.abstract: Despite significant developments in Proof Theory, surprisingly little attention has been devoted to the concept of proof verifier. In particular, mathematical community may be interested in studying different types of proof verifiers (people, programs, oracles, communities, superintelligences, etc.) as mathematical objects, their properties, their powers and limitations (particularly in human mathematicians), minimum and maximum complexity, as well as self-verification and self-reference issues in verifiers. We propose an initial classification system for verifiers and provide some rudimentary analysis of solved and open problems in this important domain. Our main contribution is a formal introduction of the notion of unverifiability, for which the paper could serve as a general citation in domains of theorem proving, software and AI verification.

sections.text: Despite significant developments in proof theory, surprisingly little attention has been paid to the concept of the verifier. Specifically, the mathematical community may be interested in examining various types of verifiers (humans, programs, oracles, communities, super-intelligences, etc.) as mathematical objects, their properties, powers and limitations (especially in human mathematics), minimum and maximum complexity, as well as self-verification and self-reference problems in verifiers. We propose an initial classification system for verifiers and provide some rudimentary analyses of solved and open problems in this important area. Our most important contribution is a formal introduction to the concept of verifiability, for which the paper could serve as a general quote in the fields of theory evidence, software and AI verification. Keywords: Verifier Theory, Proof Theory, Observer, Verifier, Verifiability.

sections.heading: 1. On Observers and Verifiers
sections.text: The concept of an "observer" manifests itself in contexts as diverse as physics (especially quantum physics), biophysics, neuroscience, cognitive science, artificial intelligence, philosophy of consciousness, relativity, and cosmology [1], but what is an equivalent idea in mathematics? We believe that it is the concept of proof "verifier." Consequently, the majority of the open questions recently raised [1] by the Institute of Principal Questions related to the physics of the observer could be asked for verifiable controls. In particular, the mathematical community might be interested in examining various kinds of verifiable controls (people, programs, oracles, communities, super-intelligences, etc.) as mathematical objects, how they can be formalized, their power and limitations (especially among human mathematicians), minimum and maximum complexity, and self-verification and self-referencing in mathematics.

sections.heading: 5. Unverifiability of Software
sections.text: Unverifiability has important consequences not only for mathematicians and philosophers of relative verification, but has also recently become an important issue in software and hardware verification, which can be regarded as special cases of verification [18, 19]. Like much of the published mathematical evidence, software is known to contain enormous amounts of errors [71], perhaps up to 50 per thousand lines of code 2, but perhaps up to 2,3 [72]. Similarly, intended interpretations are abstract machines, just as with mathematical evidence. If their intended interpretations are target machines, then we encounter the problem of determining the reliability of the verification programs themselves ("How do we verify programs?").

sections.heading: 5.1 Artificial Intelligence Unverifiability
sections.text: In fact, most of them are able to determine for themselves what they want to do.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions and Future Work
sections.text: Our early work suggests that the "verifier" could be examined as a new mathematical object of interest for future studies and predicts a significant benefit from our improved understanding of the subject. For example, an artificially intelligent verifier could be used to re-examine all previously published mathematical evidence, thereby greatly increasing the accuracy of all evidence that depends on previous work. Problems such as the infinite relapse of verifiers may be insoluble, but methods such as probabilistic verification should be able to give us as much certainty as we are willing to pay for it. Any progress in the proposed "verifier theory" will have additional benefits beyond its contribution to mathematics by making it possible to design safer advanced artificial intelligence, an issue that is set to become one of the greatest problems in science in the coming decades [85, 86].

metadata.abstractText: Despite significant developments in Proof Theory, surprisingly little attention has been devoted to the concept of proof verifier. In particular, mathematical community may be interested in studying different types of proof verifiers (people, programs, oracles, communities, superintelligences, etc.) as mathematical objects, their properties, their powers and limitations (particularly in human mathematicians), minimum and maximum complexity, as well as selfverification and self-reference issues in verifiers. We propose an initial classification system for verifiers and provide some rudimentary analysis of solved and open problems in this important domain. Our main contribution is a formal introduction of the notion of unverifiability, for which the paper could serve as a general citation in domains of theorem proving, software and AI verification.
